Glencore PLC (GLEN:LSE): Last: 86.03, up 5.17 (+6.39%), High: 87.50, Low: 81.00, Volume: 19.34m
11:07 am
PM

87p live

BE

Or rather, it's on typical daily volatility and Citi has a note out that points the convenient direction.

BE

Here is that note.

11:08 am
BE

Investor Update — We believe that all the announcements made during its
investor update including the increase in the capital preservation program ($13.1bn
from $10.2bn), reduced end-2016 debt target ($18-19bn from low 20s), strong 2016
marketing EBIT guidance ($2.4-2.7bn), and sequentially lower unit cost guidance in
2016 are steps in the right direction to enhance the balance sheet and address the
market’s concerns. While investors are waiting another streaming deal (indicated by
end-2015) and asset divestments, we remain confident in Glencore’s ability to
achieve the remaining measures during the course of 2016 and we maintain our
Buy rating on the stock with a revised PT of £1.60/share.

BE

What’s Outstanding — Of its $13.1bn capital preservation program, $8.7bn is
already achieved/locked in with outstanding bits being 1) WC reduction of $1.0bn,
indicated by mid-2016 with scope to do more. RMI is indicated to decline by another
$1bn during 2016 in addition to $2bn in 2H 15; 2) $1.9-2.9bn asset sales where
additional streaming deals are advanced for agreement by end-2015 and the sales
process for earmarked copper assets and a minority stake in the agriculture
business is under way; 3) a $500m reduction in LT loans/advanced. We see
potential asset sales as having the biggest delta and being the most market-moving.

BE

Key Changes — We incorporate all the updates into our model with unit cost
guidance resulting in the biggest impact, with significant positive revisions to EPS.
Our new EPS forecasts are 2015 $0.12 (vs. $0.09), 2016 $0.08 (vs. $-0.04) and
2017 $0.09 (vs. $-0.03). Higher earnings combined with lower capex guidance lift
our NPV estimate to £2.90/sh, from £2.30/sh, with partial offset from a higher
WACC (industrial 10.5% vs. 9% and marketing 7.5% vs. 7%), reflecting increased
beta and risk premium due to recent volatility. We lower our target EV/EBITDA
multiple to 6x (from 9x) to align with mid-cycle multiples. Our price target based on
an average of our NPV (at 10% discount) and EV/EBITDA valuations has risen to
£1.60/sh from £1.30/sh, reflecting our higher NPV and EV/EBITDA valuations.

BE

The boss's bank, in which the boss had put $174m, is getting liquidated

BE

Having been declared insolvent some time ago.

PM

And this is good news?

11:15 am
BE

It is , because there was an assumption that that money had disappeared.

BE

Now, Ferrexpo can go to the receivers like any other creditor.

BE

Which might work. Possibly.

11:16 am
BE

Here's Caz.

BE

Ferrexpo has released a short statement confirming that the banking
licence of its previous local transaction bank in Ukraine, Bank F&C, will
be revoked and the bank will be liquidated “in due course”. This follows
on from the Sep’15 announcement by the National Bank of Ukraine which
declared Bank F&C, with whom FXPO had ~$174m of funds deposited at
the time, insolvent. We believe the market had ascribed little chance of
any recourse to these funds and the attention remains firmly on a
successful renegotiation of FXPO’s pre-export facility in which covenants,
absent any change to terms, appear likely to be breached at the next testing
date.

BE

$174m deposited at Bank F&C: Bank F&C was declared insolvent in
Sep'15; at the time, FXPO had $174m of funds deposited with the bank.
Since the announcement we saw an elevated likelihood that FXPO
would be unable to recover any of the funds, particularly given the state
deposit guarantee only extended to retail deposits up to UAH200,000
(~$8,500) and in the context of the wider banking reform agenda being
driven by the National Bank of Ukraine targeting related-party
transactions (Mr. Zhevago, FXPO's CEO and largest shareholder, is a
related party to Bank F&C). FXPO now have 30 days to make a claim to
receivers although, given the related-party nature between the company
and Bank F&C, we expect the claim will be subordinated to other
creditors.

11:17 am
BE

Key near-term catalyst remains debt renegotiation: The key impact
of the insolvency is compliance with debt covenants and near-term
liquidity relating to the amortising debt facilities. The most pressing
covenant is the

BE

Top executives from US media giant Comcast have met bosses at ITV and are believed to be considering an £11 billion bid for the British broadcaster, sending its shares 4 per cent higher today.
Talks have been held between ITV and Comcast’s TV and film arm NBCUniversal, which operates the US-based NBC television channels plus a host of cable TV stations and the Universal Pictures film studio.
In opening trade, ITV shares topped the FTSE 100 leader board, up 10.5p to 274.3p.

PM

If this is true, what will Liberty have to say?

11:24 am

Dunno. Good question.

PM

They have 10%, no?

BE

Yup, and Liberty-ITV is clearly the combo that makes most sense.

11:25 am

11:26 am
BE

Anyway, this all dovetails into recent rumours about Comcast taking a greater interest in the UK TV market.

BE

Because it's not had a domestic hit for two years, and could really use a functioning production company.

11:27 am

Sky PLC (SKY:LSE): Last: 1,093, up 13 (+1.20%), High: 1,097, Low: 1,079, Volume: 521.97k
BE

11:28 am
BE

I'd not see these two stories in isolation.

BE

Anyway, here's Nomura.

BE

A GBP11bn bid for ITV would imply a share price of 275p or a 2016 PE of 15.5x which in our view would seem relatively low, particularly given that Liberty holds a 10% stake which would raise the competitive positioning in any bidding scenario (note our DCF implies a target price of 320p). The key attraction for any bid would be ITV’s content with ITV Studios currently accounting for c.30% of revenue which we believe could rise to around 50% assuming a continuation of the groups M&A.

11:29 am
BE

Oh, forgot to mention the £11bn thing, which is clearly too low.

BE

11:31 am
BE

That suspicion might tie in with my earlier suspicions with reference to Sky.

BE

But, I stress, I've no info. Suspicions only.

What is a Watchstone anyway? It's not a touchstone and it's not a watchword.

11:35 am
BE

There must be a Quindell parallel here, but I'm struggling to find it.

BE

Have some research instead. Peel Hunt.

BE

After a long period of turbulence, having exited the personal
injury business, returned £414m to shareholders, and re-named
from Quindell to Watchstone Group under its new management,
is a changed proposition. It is now much more focused,
particularly on the rapidly evolving Usage Based Insurance and
healthcare technology markets, where there is much to play for
and where it has valuable customer relationships and a strong
product. Although historical issues are relevant to assessing
contingent liabilities, management has made rapid progress, the
group is fully funded with £90m of cash and a further £55m in
escrow, and investors can now look to the future. Our TP is a
15% discount to our low end valuation of 210p per share, with
upside as issues and opportunities clarify.

11:35 am
BE

For several months, management has been resolving major historical accounting,
strategic, reporting, management and acquisition-related issues. This research
note has been prepared with a view to assisting investors on a forward-looking
basis, discussing legacy issues only insofar as they affect today’s investment case.
There remain a number of unknowns, for which investors should allow, but the
group is well funded for its immediate future.
Investors now need to be convinced of the group’s strategy. Management is
pulling together a number of insurance-related technology businesses to form its
new brand Hubio to provide an integrated solution to connect people, devices
and systems within the insurance and automotive sectors. pt Health provides a
good base for developing a valuable business in healthcare technology. With a
platform for growth established, 2016 should see value clarify, risks reduce, noncore
assets rationalised and contingent assets and liabilities become clearer.
We have undertaken extensive due diligence, including visiting five operating
sites (including in the US), spoken to industry partners and to competitors.
We have prepared financial forecasts and SOTP valuations under low, mid
and high scenarios, which at this stage should be taken as illustrative only.
Our low-end fair value of 210p per share gives little value to the operating
businesses, but allows for substantial litigation, warranty and liability risk,
therefore providing upside as these are resolved. We allow for an additional 15%
discount in our TP to account further for valuation and execution risk. Our midcase
valuation is 494p per share.

Anyway, RBC is a seller of ABF this morning.

Associated British Foods PLC (ABF:LSE): Last: 3,265, down 62.4 (-1.88%), High: 3,305, Low: 3,255, Volume: 287.64k
11:39 am
BE

Argues that Primark's lack of online might eventually become a bad thing

BE

Having so far been a brilliant thing, because it saves needless capex, doesn't put the brand at the mercy of Yodel or whoever, and actually forces people into the stores.

BE

Where they end up buying £5 hoodies they wouldn't imagine buying in any circumstances other than when they're addled by Primark's zoo-like experience.

11:41 am
BE

Here's RBC.

BE

Our view: We think ABF's valuation (32x cal. 16 P/E) is relatively full given
a lack of EPS momentum and as we expect Primark's LFL growth to remain
moderate. ABF has a strong management team but it faces cost and
currency headwinds and we think Primark's longer term profit pool may
be constrained by a lack of online exposure. We move to Underperform
from Sector Perform.

BE

Reducing EPS forecasts by 3-4% – we have reduced our FY17/18 EPS
forecasts by 3-4% for ABF mainly owing to a weaker expected performance
from main business Primark (c.60% of group profit). Partly offsetting this
is a slightly stronger expected trading performance by the Grocery and
Ingredients businesses and we have raised our profit forecasts for lower
rated AB Sugar owing to an improved pricing outlook.
Implied valuation for Primark full – backing out the non-Primark
businesses at a 2016 P/E of 18-22x suggests Primark is trading at c.39-42x
cal. 16 P/E which we consider full given expected moderate LFL sales
growth (1% for FY15 and FY16E).
Discount sector faces a number of challenges – we think the discount
sector as a whole faces cost pressure from dollar sourcing (c.80% of the
total) and from rising wage pressures as a result of the introduction of the
national living wage from April 2016. Discount shoppers tend to be price
sensitive and we think it is relatively more difficult to raise prices without
them noticing and sales volumes being impacted.

11:41 am
BE

US expansion off to a strong start but only two stores open so far –
Primark has made an encouraging start in the US market with compelling
price points and very attractive stores. However we still think it will take
time for Primark to adapt its offer there store by store and the market is
highly price competitive.
Lack of online to constrain Primark's longer term profit pool – we
continue to see a structural shift from store to online based clothing
retailing which has reached c.20% of the market in the UK. While this has
not affected Primark's growth so far we think its longer term profit pool
may be constrained by its relatively low basket size making the economics
of online delivery costs unviable.
Grocery and Ingredients in good shape; Sugar past the worst but a lower
multiple business – Grocery and Ingredients will face a high single digit
currency headwind on sales in H1 but we think they are trading well.
Meanwhile the EU and world sugar pricing environment appears to have
stabilised in advance of EU quota removal in 2017. We see potential for
sugar profits to rebound strongly from FY17 but listed peers trade at
relatively low multiples.

11:43 am
BE

Our view: We upgrade Dixons Carphone to Top Pick as we expect further
market share gains, positive newsflow on its higher rated Connected
World Services business (incl. Sprint), a potential property restructuring
programme, further margin progression and a stronger TV upgrade cycle
in 2016. We believe valuation is attractive at 15x CY16E PE for a 13% EPS
CAGR (CY15-18e).

PM

(cheeckychappy -- three daughters)

BE

"stronger TV upgrade cycle in 2016" ......... Why?

11:43 am
BE

Undervalued growth potential from Sprint/Connected World Services:
We believe that Dixons Carphone will soon announce a full roll-out of 500
new Sprint stores after a successful 15-store trial in Chicago and Miami.
We also think that there could be an opportunity for CWS to run existing
Sprint stores in the US and expect the launch of HoneyBee in the US in
2016. In our view, Connected World Services is highly scalable globally
and should provide high future returns given its low capital intensity. We
forecast CWS EBIT of £70m by 2020 (see Dixons Carphone - Sprinting
ahead for more detail) We also think there is an opportunity to widen the
US shareholder base as was the case when CPW owned a 50% share of
Best Buy Mobile in the US.
Potential acceleration of UK store closures: We think that Dixons
Carphone may decide to accelerate the number of UK store closures and
potentially reduce the target Currys/PC World estate to below 380 stores.
Whilst this may result in a larger exceptional property loss charge, Dixons
Carphone has been achieving good paybacks on closures and there is
currently strong demand from the likes of B&M for out-of-town space. We
also think a focus on the 3-in-1 store format in the UK could result in the
closure of some of the overlapping out-of-town legacy CPW stores. Any
property restructuring plan should be taken well by the market as Dixons
Carphone streamlines its cost base and focuses on driving further growth
from fewer, higher density 3-in-1 stores.

PM

Wonder what the margins are now on TVs

BE

Likely Black Friday winner: We think that Dixons Carphone had a strong
Black Friday weekend which according to Experian-IMRG was up greater than 35% on
last year. John Lewis also commented on a strong weekend for electricals
and this year Currys offered 30% more deals and 40% more stock than last
year and avoided the use of a queuing system.
Undemanding valuation for strong longer-term growth potential: Dixons
Carphone currently trades on 15x CY16E PE with an EPS CAGR (CY15-18e)
of 13%. We see potential for further margin expansion in FY16 and
FY17 led by market share gains in the UK and as the synergy benefits
are realised. Longer term, we expect growth to come from CWS as the
Sprint deal should yield upside from FY18. Our estimates are c2% above
consensus and we upgrade Dixons Carphone to Top Pick.

11:48 am
BE

Outperform (prev: Top Pick)

BE

Our view: We think M&S' online execution has been stronger this year,
strong buying gains should extend into next year and its food offer should
continue to outperform. Also valuation is undemanding with strong
cash generation providing scope for multi-year cash returns. We remain
positive on the shares but are mindful of soft clothing LFLs and subdued
international demand near term.

BE

Remain positive on long term fundamentals – we remain positive on
M&S' longer term fundamentals i.e a) an online catch up with margins
trending towards the group average in 1-2 years. b) leverage to the
UK consumer which should continue to benefit from rising disposable
income c) an outperforming premium events driven food business d)
multi-year gross margin improvements driven by buying gains and in
time potentially lower markdown, and e) strong cash generation enabling
scope for additional cash returns.
Valuation undemanding – M&S' shares have been weak in recent weeks
mainly owing to current trading concerns. We still deem M&S' shares
attractive at a valuation of 12x CY16 PE, offering a 4% dividend yield and
c.9% FCF yield post pension contributions.
Focus on improving availability in clothing – although we think M&S
has improved its systems, supply chain and offer, we think it will take
time to improve the availability of core lines and also recapture its value
credentials in womenswear. We also think that International trends will
likely remain soft short term mainly owing to a combination of macro and
currency challenges.

The Company notes the recent press speculation and confirms that it has held discussions with the board of Sportech PLC in relation to a potential acquisition of The Football Pools business (the "Acquisition"). These discussions are at a very preliminary stage and there is no guarantee that any agreement will be reached.

BE

Football Pools is fascinating. It's considered a game of chance rather than skill, which is an important legal qualification.

11:50 am
PM

The Football Pools business is the world’s oldest football gaming company.
Founded in 1923, outside the world famous Old Trafford football stadium, The Football Pools has been based in Liverpool since that day and recently celebrated its 90th anniversary.
As part of the anniversary celebrations a host of Footballing legends, including Alan Hansen and Gordon Banks helped to recreate the scene.

PM

The Football Pools (the brand created when Littlewoods and Vernons Pools combined in 2008) is owned and operated by Sportech PLC, one of the world’s leading pools and tote gaming companies.
Sportech has a presence in over 30 jurisdictions, and process over £8 Billion in pools and tote bets annually.
The Football Pools are committed to leaving a lasting legacy, not only for its millions of players, but also through its support of good causes.

BE

One upshot of the game-of-chance thing is that footballers themselves are allowed to play the pools.

BE

According to comments in the press today, it appears that SYK is moving ahead with a
proposed bid for SNN. The company currently holds ~24% share in the global hip and
knee market and the deal would increase its share position to ~35%, putting the
company closer on par with the other two remaining players – ZBH and JNJ/DePuy.
Recall that SYK bidding for SNN has been widely reported in the press and addressed
by SYK management since at least mid-2014. Our initial analysis puts the deal at ~5-
13% cash accretive in year one, improving in years 2 and beyond. We remain Neutral
on SYK for now, but would view the prospective deal as a positive for the stock and the
group.

BE

Main risks appear to be regulatory approval and sales dis-synergies
In our view, the main risks to the potential acquisition would be regulatory approval
(and possible divestment requirements) and sales dis-synergies. The companies have
overlap in areas including trauma, robotics and selective large joint reconstruction.
Precedent transactions include JNJ divesting its trauma business to Biomet as part of the
Synthes acquisition, Zimmer divesting its ZUK knee business and Discovery Elbow in
Japan to Lima Corporate as part of the Biomet deal and Wright Medical selling its Salto
ankle to Integra LifeSciences as part of the Tornier deal.

BE

($18bn) would put S&N on 12.8x 2015
consensus EV/ EBITDA and a ~16% premium to Thursday night’s close.
Valuation: $105 Target, 13.0x EV/EBITDA multiple on 2017E EBITDA of $2.9 bil
We view the premium to closest comp ZBH as warranted given the company's superior
NOA efficiency and capital returns profile.
